stupendous.meaning: so great in size, force, or extent as to elicit awe
stupendous.breif: Stupendous means amazing or awesome. You just won a million dollars and are donating it to charity? That’s stupendous!

adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

ersatz.meaning: an artificial or inferior substitute or imitation
ersatz.breif: The ersatz version of something is an inferior substitute or imitation. You might speak in an ersatz French accent, but you won't fool the Parisian who runs the local French bakery.

noun: an artificial or inferior substitute or imitation
adjective: artificial and inferior

admonish.meaning: scold or reprimand; take to task
admonish.breif: To admonish is to scold. If you want to show someone you're not happy with his behavior, admonish him.

verb: admonish or counsel in terms of someone's behavior

example: He admonished the child for his bad behavior

tyro.meaning: someone new to a field or activity
tyro.breif: A tyro is a beginner, a new recruit, or someone who is just learning something. If you are the new guy at the job and you're wearing a big badge that says "Trainee" on it, you are a tyro.

noun: someone new to a field or activity

aphrodisiac.meaning: a drug or other agent that stimulates sexual desire
aphrodisiac.breif: An aphrodisiac is a drug (or something else) that puts people in the mood for sex.

noun: a drug or other agent that stimulates sexual desire
adjective: exciting sexual desire

besmirch.meaning: smear so as to make dirty or stained
besmirch.breif: To besmirch means to dirty or tarnish, particularly someone's reputation — like when you call Billy a cheater at kickball (even though you know he's just better at bunting than you).

verb: smear so as to make dirty or stained
charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone

panacea.meaning: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases
panacea.breif: If someone offers you a pill that promises eternal life, don’t take the pill.  It’s a panacea, a remedy that falsely claims to solve every problem ever.

noun: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; once sought by the alchemists

epithet.breif: The noun epithet is a descriptive nickname, such as "Richard the Lionhearted," or "Tommy the Terrible." When it takes a turn for the worse, it can also be a word or phrase that offends.

noun: descriptive word or phrase
a defamatory or abusive word or phrase

ostracize.meaning: expel from a community or group
ostracize.breif: If you banish someone or ignore him, you ostracize him. When the Iranian president claimed that the Holocaust was a hoax, he was ostracized by the international community.

verb: expel from a community or group
avoid speaking to or dealing with

example: Ever since I spoke up, my colleagues ostracize me

placebo.breif: A patient's symptoms sometimes disappear just because they believe that they are being treated. Even when doctors give them a biologically inactive drug, otherwise known as a placebo, the patients swear they are cured.

noun: an innocuous or inert medication; given as a pacifier or to the control group in experiments on the efficacy of a drug
(Roman Catholic Church) vespers of the office for the dead

fiasco.breif: A fiasco is a disaster. It's not a natural disaster — like an earthquake or a volcano; a fiasco is usually the result of human failure.

noun: a complete failure or collapse

dichotomy.meaning: a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses
dichotomy.breif: A dichotomy is an idea or classification split in two. When you point out a dichotomy, you draw a clear distinction between two things.

noun: being twofold; a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses

example: the dichotomy between eastern and western culture

coterie.meaning: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose
coterie.breif: Have you noticed how so many of the best TV shows concentrate on a group of friends who seem to mesh together perfectly, to the exclusion of all others? This, then, is a coterie, an exclusive group with common interests.

noun: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose

euphemism.meaning: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
euphemism.breif: Pardon me, but when a polite term is substituted for a blunt, offensive one, you should call it a euphemism.

noun: an inoffensive or indirect expression that is substituted for one that is considered offensive or too harsh

zealot.meaning: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
zealot.breif: The hamburger zealot was so fanatical about his burgers that he camped outside his favorite fast-food joint for hours every morning, waiting for it to open. And he would never put mustard on them, only ketchup.

noun: a fervent and even militant proponent of something

mesmerize.meaning: attract strongly, as if with a magnet
mesmerize.breif: You meet someone and you can’t take your eyes off them, like you are connected by an invisible cord and can’t break free.  Those kinds of people have the power to mesmerize, holding your attention like you’re under hypnosis.

verb: attract strongly, as if with a magnet

paragon.meaning: a perfect embodiment of a concept
paragon.breif: Paragon applies to someone who is a model of perfection in some quality or trait. We link paragon with other words that follow it, such as "paragon of virtue" or "paragon of patience."

noun: an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept
model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal

dilettante.meaning: an amateur engaging in an activity without serious intention
dilettante.breif: Though dilettante might sound like a nice French word, don't use it on your friend who thinks he can play the guitar after several short lessons. A dilettante is an amateur, often one who pretends to be very knowledgeable.

noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
adjective: showing frivolous or superficial interest; amateurish

hyperbole.breif: Praising your favorite sports team is one thing, but if you call the team the most incredible group of humans ever to walk the earth, then you're going overboard and indulging in hyperbole.

noun: extravagant exaggeration

extravagant.breif: Extravagant is an adjective that means expensive, excessive, and over the top. A modest chandelier in your dining room is normal. But crystal-studded walls and gold-plated goblets? That's a bit extravagant.

adjective: recklessly wasteful
extremely or unreasonably high in price
greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
characterized by extravagance and profusion
unrestrained, especially with regard to feelings

pedant.meaning: a person who pays too much attention to formal rules
pedant.breif: A pedant is an annoying person who is focused on minor details and book knowledge rather than ordinary common sense. In war, it can be dangerous to have a pedant as commander — he'll insist on textbook maneuvers instead of adapting to circumstances on the ground.

noun: a person who pays more attention to formal rules and book learning than they merit

apotheosis.meaning: model of excellence or perfection of a kind
apotheosis.breif: If your teacher says the term paper you handed in last week is a work of genius that sets a new gold standard for the school, he's telling you your work is the apotheosis of term papers. The epitome. Perfection.

noun: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal
the elevation of a person (as to the status of a god)

sycophant.meaning: a person who tries to please someone to gain an advantage
sycophant.breif: A sycophant is a person who tries to win favor from wealthy or influential people by flattering them. Also known as brown-nosers, teacher's pets or suck-ups.

noun: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

dogma.meaning: a doctrine or code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
dogma.breif: Dogma means the doctrine of belief in a religion or a political system.

noun: a doctrine or code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
a religious doctrine that is proclaimed as true without proof

example: he believed all the Marxist dogma

misanthrope.meaning: someone who dislikes people in general
misanthrope.breif: A misanthrope is a person who hates or mistrusts other people. Your great aunt Edna who lashes out at anyone who approaches, convinced they'll steal the jewelry she keeps in her handbag on her lap? A misanthrope indeed.

noun: someone who dislikes people in general

dissonance.breif: Disagreeable sounds can be called dissonance. You know it's dissonance if you have the strong desire to cover your ears with your hands.

noun: disagreeable sounds
the auditory experience of sound that lacks musical quality; sound that is a disagreeable auditory experience
a conflict of people's opinions or actions or characters

histrionic.breif: Anything that has to do with actors or acting can be called  histrionic, like a Broadway actor's histrionic voice projection that would sound strange in everyday life but is perfect for the stage.

adjective: overly dramatic or emotional
characteristic of acting or a stage performance; affected

esoteric.meaning: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.breif: Pssst... do you know the secret handshake? If you haven't been brought into the inner circle of those with special knowledge, esoteric things will remain a mystery to you.

adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle

example: a compilation of esoteric philosophical theories

nuance.meaning: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.breif: Use nuance to refer to a very small difference in color, meaning, or feeling. What makes singers brilliant is not how loud they can sing a note, but how many nuances they can evoke through their approach.

noun: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude

example: without understanding the finer nuances you can't enjoy the humor

aficionado.meaning: a serious devotee of some activity, genre, or performer
aficionado.breif: If you really like something and make it your business to study up on its history and characteristics, you could be called an aficionado of that subject.

noun: a serious devotee of some particular music genre or musical performer
a fan of bull fighting

idiosyncratic.breif: Idiosyncratic means unique to an individual. Albert Einstein famously had lots of idiosyncratic habits.  For example, he rarely wore socks, and he talked to his cat.

adjective: peculiar to the individual

example: we all have our own idiosyncratic gestures

rubric.breif: A rubric is a heading or a category in a chart, or a rule of conduct. A teacher's grading rubrics may include participation, homework completion, tests, quizzes, and papers.

noun: category name
a title or heading that is printed in red or in a special type
a heading that names a statute or legislative bill; may give a brief summary of the matters it deals with
an authoritative rule of conduct or procedure
directions for the conduct of Christian church services (often printed in red in a prayer book)
an explanation or definition of an obscure word in a text

example: it is usually discussed under the rubric of `functional obesity'

travesty.meaning: a composition that imitates or misrepresents a style
travesty.breif: A travesty is a cheap mockery, usually of something or someone serious, such as a travesty of justice.

noun: a composition that imitates or misrepresents somebody's style, usually in a humorous way
a comedy characterized by broad satire and improbable situations
a distorted, debased, or absurd imitation of something

prescience.meaning: the power to foresee the future
prescience.breif: Do you already know what happens tomorrow? Next week? Next year? If you can see into the future, then you have prescience.

noun: the power to foresee the future

equivocate.breif: When you are unwilling to make a decision and almost intentionally go back and forth between two choices, you are equivocating. When politicians equivocate, they are often afraid of upsetting, and thus alienating, voters with their decisions.

verb: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead or withhold information

vexation.meaning: anger produced by some annoying irritation
vexation.breif: Vexation is both something that causes annoyance and the state of mind that results from being annoyed. The test-taker next to you tapping her pencil is a vexation. You breaking her pencil in half makes her feel vexation.

noun: anger produced by some annoying irritation
the psychological state of being irritated or annoyed
something or someone that causes anxiety; a source of unhappiness
the act of troubling or annoying someone

obduracy.meaning: resoluteness by virtue of being unyielding and inflexible

noun: resoluteness by virtue of being unyielding and inflexible

fiefdom.meaning: the domain controlled by a feudal lord

noun: the domain controlled by a feudal lord
an organization that is controlled by a dominant person or group

anachronism.meaning: locating something at a time when it couldn't have existed
anachronism.breif: An anachronism is something that doesn't fit its time period, like if you say you'll "dial" your smartphone.

noun: the act of locating something at a time when it could not have existed or occurred
an artifact that belongs to another time
a person who seems to be displaced in time; who belongs to another age

egregious.meaning: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible
egregious.breif: Something that is egregious stands out, but not in a good way — it means "really bad or offensive." If you make an egregious error during a championship soccer match, your coach might bench you for the rest of the game.

adjective: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible

profusion.meaning: the property of being extremely abundant
profusion.breif: If there's an abundance of something, you can say that there's a profusion of it. Hilarious and bizarre YouTube videos certainly exist in profusion.

noun: the property of being extremely abundant

acrimony.breif: Acrimony is bitterness, or ill will. Acrimony is a spiteful word. It sounds bitter, like acid.

noun: a rough and bitter manner

exacerbate.breif: For a formal-sounding verb that means to make worse, try exacerbate. If you're in trouble, complaining about it will only exacerbate the problem.

curmudgeon.meaning: an irascible, cantankerous person full of stubborn ideas
curmudgeon.breif: Old, cranky, and more than a little stubborn, a curmudgeon is the gruff, grey-haired neighbor who refuses to hand out candy at Halloween and shoos away holiday carolers with a "bah humbug!"

noun: a crusty irascible cantankerous old person full of stubborn ideas

innocuous.meaning: not injurious to physical or mental health
innocuous.breif: Something that's innocuous isn't harmful or likely to cause injury. Public figures like mayors and governors have to expect they'll get critical or even hurtful emails and phone calls, as well as more innocuous feedback.

adjective: not injurious to physical or mental health
lacking intent or capacity to injure
not causing disapproval

anathema.meaning: a formal ecclesiastical curse accompanied by excommunication
anathema.breif: Something that one absolutely and positively cannot stand is anathema. Garlic is anathema to vampires (ditto for stakes and daylight). So is kryptonite to Superman or a silver bullet to a werewolf.

noun: a formal ecclesiastical curse accompanied by excommunication
a detested person or thing
something that inspires dislike; something horrible

example: he is an anathema to me

haughty.breif: Someone who is haughty is arrogant and full of pride. When you're haughty, you have a big attitude and act like you're better than other people.

adjective: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy

asceticism.breif: Asceticism is rigorous self-denial, particularly the rejection of the pleasures of the world. If you don't drink, smoke, eat sugar, see movies, use the internet, or have a cell phone, then you are already practicing a kind of asceticism.

noun: rigorous self-denial and active self-restraint
the trait of great self-denial (especially refraining from worldly pleasures)
the doctrine that through renunciation of worldly pleasures it is possible to achieve a high spiritual or intellectual state

imprimatur.breif: If you give something your imprimatur, you give it your formal support or approval. An imprimatur is a fancy version of a thumbs-up sign.

noun: formal and explicit approval

sardonic.breif: If someone is being scornful and mocking in a humorous way, call her sardonic. If you want to write comic sketches for late-night talk shows, work on being sardonic.

adjective: disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking

example: "his rebellion is the bitter, sardonic laughter of all great satirists"- Frank Schoenberner

ameliorate.breif: To ameliorate is to step in and make a bad situation better. You could try introducing a second lollipop to ameliorate a battle between two toddlers over a single lollipop.

turpitude.meaning: a corrupt or depraved or degenerate act or practice
turpitude.breif: If you are guilty of turpitude, you should be ashamed of yourself. Turpitude is a word that represents depraved behavior. Prisons are filled with criminals who have engaged in acts of moral turpitude.

noun: a corrupt or depraved or degenerate act or practice

example: the various turpitudes of modern society

dalliance.meaning: the act of delaying and playing instead of working
dalliance.breif: A dalliance is a playful flirtation, one that might lead to a casual romance. The king's public dalliance toward the lady in waiting shocked everyone in the court except for the queen.

noun: the deliberate act of delaying and playing instead of working
playful behavior intended to arouse romantic interest

autodidact.meaning: a person who has taught himself
autodidact.breif: If you're an autodidact you've done most of your learning on your own, outside of school. Having learned Greek and Latin, as well as landscape painting and auto repair, without any formal training makes you quite the autodidact.

noun: a person who has taught himself

evanescent.meaning: short-lived; tending to vanish or disappear
evanescent.breif: A beautiful sunset, a rainbow, a wonderful dream right before your alarm clock goes off — all of these could be described as evanescent, which means “fleeting” or “temporary.”

adjective: tending to vanish like vapor

interlude.breif: An interlude is a brief period of time that comes in the middle of something. You might enjoy a relaxing lemonade interlude in the middle of a tough day at your road-paving job.

noun: an intervening period or episode
a brief show (music or dance etc) inserted between the sections of a longer performance

example: The guitar player interluded with a beautiful improvisation

demure.meaning: shy or modest, often in a playful or provocative way
demure.breif: A demure person can be described as polite and a little shy. A demure outfit is a modest one — think high neckline and low hem.

adjective: affectedly modest or shy especially in a playful or provocative way
(used especially of clothing) suggestive of modesty or reserve

mellifluous.breif: Use the adjective mellifluous to describe something that sounds sweet and smooth, like the honeyed voice of a late-night radio DJ.

adjective: pleasing to the ear

felicity.meaning: pleasing and appropriate manner or style
felicity.breif: Felicity is a state of happiness or the quality of joy. Sitting on the roof with a telescope and iced tea on a clear, starry night is one way to find perfect felicity — a happy place.

noun: pleasing and appropriate manner or style (especially manner or style of expression)
state of well-being characterized by emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy

imbroglio.meaning: an intricate and confusing interpersonal situation
imbroglio.breif: An imbroglio is a complicated or confusing personal situation. To rephrase the J. Geils band song, "Love Stinks," if you love her and she loves him and he loves somebody else, you've got quite an imbroglio.

noun: an intricate and confusing interpersonal or political situation
a very embarrassing misunderstanding

insouciance.meaning: a casual or lighthearted feeling of unconcern
insouciance.breif: Insouciance is a feeling of careless indifference. There's a certain amount of lightheartedness in insouciance, but rather than merely being cheerful, someone with insouciance truly couldn't care less.

noun: the cheerful feeling you have when nothing is troubling you

lassitude.meaning: a feeling of lack of interest or energy
lassitude.breif: If you are feeling lassitude, you're weary and just can't be bothered. Couch potatoes make lassitude into an art form.

noun: a feeling of lack of interest or energy
weakness characterized by a lack of vitality or energy
a state of comatose torpor (as found in sleeping sickness)

lucid.breif: Something that's lucid is clear and understandable. Lucid writing is important in journalism, so that readers easily get the point of the article they're reading.

adjective: (of language) transparently clear; easily understandable
having a clear mind
capable of thinking and expressing yourself in a clear and consistent manner
transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity

example: a lucid moment in his madness

elysian.meaning: relating to the abode of the blessed after death
elysian.breif: The adjective elysian describes a blissful state, like the one most people hope to enjoy on a Hawaiian vacation.

adjective: relating to the Elysian Fields
being of such surpassing excellence as to suggest inspiration by the gods

neophyte.meaning: a participant with no experience with an activity
neophyte.breif: A neophyte is someone who's brand new at something. You're a neophyte the first time you pick up a guitar and start learning to play.

noun: a participant with no experience with an activity
a new convert being taught the principles of Christianity by a catechist
a plant that is found in an area where it had not been recorded previously

rapture.meaning: a state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion
rapture.breif: Rapture is a feeling of emotional ecstasy so magical it's almost as if you've been transported to some other world.

noun: a state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion
a state of elated bliss

example: "listening to sweet music in a perfect rapture"- Charles Dickens

evocative.breif: Use the adjective evocative when you want to describe something that reminds you of something else. If your mom baked a lot when you were a kid, the smell of cookies in the oven is probably evocative of your childhood.

adjective: serving to bring to mind

antipathy.breif: An antipathy is a deep-seated dislike of something or someone. Usually it's a condition that is long-term, innate, and pretty unlikely to change — like your antipathy for the Red Sox.

noun: a feeling of intense dislike
the object of a feeling of intense aversion; something to be avoided

affinity.meaning: a natural attraction or feeling of kinship
affinity.breif: If you get along with someone very well, you have an affinity with them. Sometimes opposites attract, so you might feel a strange affinity to someone who is seemingly very different from you.

noun: a natural attraction or feeling of kinship
a close connection marked by community of interests or similarity in nature or character
(anthropology) kinship by marriage or adoption; not a blood relationship
(biology) state of relationship between organisms or groups of organisms resulting in resemblance in structure or structural parts
inherent resemblance between persons or things
the force attracting atoms to each other and binding them together in a molecule
(immunology) the attraction between an antigen and an antibody

example: found a natural affinity with the immigrants
in anatomical structure prehistoric man shows close affinity with modern humans
basic dyes have an affinity for wool and silk

empathy.meaning: understanding and entering into another's feelings
empathy.breif: Use empathy if you're looking for a noun meaning "the ability to identify with another's feelings."

noun: understanding and entering into another's feelings

anomaly.meaning: deviation from the normal or common order, form, or rule
anomaly.breif: An anomaly is an abnormality, a blip on the screen of life that doesn’t fit with the rest of the pattern. If you are a breeder of black dogs and one puppy comes out pink, that puppy is an anomaly.

noun: deviation from the normal or common order or form or rule
a person who is unusual
(astronomy) position of a planet as defined by its angular distance from its perihelion (as observed from the sun)

hoi polloi.breif: The hoi polloi is a way of referring to common people, and it is an elitist term usually used by people who consider themselves to be above the masses.

noun: the common people generally

paramount.meaning: more important than anything else; supreme
paramount.breif: To the President, protecting our nation's security is of paramount importance — it's at the very top of his to-do list.

adjective: more important than anything else; supreme
having superior power or influence

antagonize.breif: To antagonize is to provoke someone to react angrily. If your mother tells you to stop antagonizing your brother, she's asking you to stop making him mad.

arrant.breif: The word arrant intensifies. An arrant criminal is one heck of a criminal. Arrant nonsense is total nonsense.

adjective: without qualification; used informally as (often pejorative) intensifiers

errant.meaning: straying from the right course or from accepted standards
errant.breif: Something or someone described as errant has gone astray or done wrong by going in an unexpected direction. An errant bird might end up in northern Canada while his friends fly to southern Mexico for the winter.

adjective: straying from the right course or from accepted standards
moving in an uncontrolled, irregular, or unpredictable way
traveling from place to place, especially in search of adventure

adulterate.meaning: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
adulterate.breif: If you adulterate something, you mess it up. You may not want to adulterate the beauty of freshly fallen snow by shoveling it, but how else are you going to get to work?

verb: corrupt, debase, or make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance; often by replacing valuable ingredients with inferior ones
adjective: mixed with impurities

bedaze.meaning: overcome as with astonishment or disbelief

verb: overcome as with astonishment or disbelief

craven.meaning: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
craven.breif: A craven man is no Superman or Spiderman, nor is he a firefighter or a soldier. A craven man is the opposite of those guys: he has not an ounce of courage.

adjective: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
noun: an abject coward

example: the craven fellow turned and ran

prevaricate.breif: When you prevaricate, you lie or mislead. Now, go ahead and tell me whether you already knew that meaning, and don’t prevaricate about it — give me the story straight!

verb: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead or withhold information

gregarious.meaning: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
gregarious.breif: If you know someone who's outgoing, sociable, and fond of the company of others, you might want to call her gregarious.

adjective: instinctively or temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
(of animals) tending to form a group with others of the same species
(of plants) growing in groups that are close together

example: he is a gregarious person who avoids solitude

iconoclast.meaning: someone who attacks cherished ideas or institutions
iconoclast.breif: Are you always challenging the establishment? Or provoking popular thought by attacking traditions and institutions? Then you're definitely an iconoclast.

noun: someone who attacks cherished ideas or traditional institutions
a destroyer of images used in religious worship

assail.breif: To assail is to attack or assault — with throwing stars, fists, words or, less tangibly but just as violently, with troubles or doubts.

verb: launch an attack or assault on; begin hostilities or start warfare with

example: Serbian forces assailed Bosnian towns all week

denounce.breif: To denounce is to tattle, rat out, or speak out against something. When you stand on your desk and tell the class that your partner is cheating, you denounce him or her.

verb: accuse or condemn openly or formally as disgraceful
announce the termination of, as of treaties

castigate.breif: Use castigate  when you mean "to reprimand in an especially harsh way." If you accidentally spill coffee all over your sister's favorite sweater, you might worry that she's going to castigate you as soon as she finds out.

diatribe.breif: It's pretty overwhelming when you ask your friend a seemingly innocuous question, like "Do you like hot dogs?" and she unleashes a diatribe about the evils of eating meat. A diatribe is an angry, critical speech.

noun: thunderous verbal attack

excoriate.breif: When it comes to “telling someone off,” excoriate is reserved for the most severe cases. So, before you excoriate your little sister for borrowing your favorite jacket without permission, consider whether she truly deserves such harsh treatment.

verb: tear or wear off the skin or make sore by abrading

fulminate.meaning: cause to explode violently and with loud noise
fulminate.breif: Watch a bomb fulminate or explode and hope you're under safe cover. Have your parents fulminate or blow up at you for coming home past curfew and hope you're not grounded for too long.

verb: cause to explode violently and with loud noise
noun: a salt or ester of fulminic acid

example: He fulminated against the Republicans' plan to cut Medicare

bombastic.breif: To be bombastic is to be full of hot air — like a politician who makes grand promises and doesn't deliver.

adjective: ostentatiously lofty in style

lambaste.breif: To lambaste is to reprimand or berate someone severely. People lambaste those who have angered or disappointed them.

revile.breif: If something is reviled, you alone don’t dislike it; a whole community of like-minded souls has to hate its guts. For instance, spam is widely reviled. (The junk e-mails, not the potted meat. Somebody out there really does like that potted meat.)

tirade.breif: A tirade is a speech, usually consisting of a long string of violent, emotionally charged words. Borrow and lose your roommate’s clothes one too many times, and you can bet you’ll be treated to a heated tirade.

noun: a speech of violent denunciation

upbraid.breif: No, upbraid isn’t an elaborate hairdo. When you upbraid people, you scold them, tell them off, and criticize them. (You could, however, upbraid your stylist after a bad haircut.)

drub.meaning: beat thoroughly and conclusively in a competition or fight

verb: beat thoroughly and conclusively in a competition or fight

pulverize.meaning: make into a powder by breaking up or cause to become dust
pulverize.breif: When you pulverize something, you break it up until it becomes dust or powder. You might pulverize coffee beans in grinder, running it until the coffee turns to powder.

verb: make into a powder by breaking up or cause to become dust

example: pulverize the rebellion before it gets out of hand

subjugate.meaning: make subservient; force to submit or subdue
subjugate.breif: If you say you won't be kept down by the man, you are saying that you won't let the man subjugate you. To subjugate is to repress someone, or to make them subservient to you.

verb: make subservient; force to submit or subdue
put down by force or intimidation

example: The rich landowners subjugated the peasants working the land

vanquish.meaning: defeat in a competition, race, or conflict
vanquish.breif: To vanquish is to be the complete and total winner, to overpower and overcome, whether in a contest, a race, or a war. It generally suggests a total trouncing, to the point of humiliation — or worse — for the loser.

verb: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

capitulate.breif: To capitulate means to give in to something. If your parents refuse to raise your allowance, you might try to argue until they capitulate. Good luck!

axiom.meaning: a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof
axiom.breif: An axiom is a statement that everyone believes is true, such as "the only constant is change." Mathematicians use the word axiom to refer to an established proof.

noun: (logic) a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof; its truth is assumed to be self-evident
a saying that is widely accepted on its own merits

approbation.breif: Approbation is a formal word for approval or praise. Approbation is like getting the nod in a big way. Politicians rely on the public’s approbation to get elected.

noun: official approval
official recognition or approval

belligerent.meaning: characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight
belligerent.breif: If someone is belligerent, they're eager to fight. It's a good idea to avoid hardcore hockey fans after their team loses — they tend to be belligerent.

adjective: characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight
engaged in war
noun: someone who fights (or is fighting)

capricious.meaning: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
capricious.breif: Capricious is an adjective to describe a person or thing that's impulsive and unpredictable, like a bride who suddenly leaves her groom standing at the wedding altar.

adjective: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
changeable

reprimand.meaning: an act or expression of criticism and censure
reprimand.breif: If you're reprimanded, someone in authority speaks to you in an angry way because you've done something wrong. Or you might reprimand your dog if he steals your hot dog.

noun: an act or expression of criticism and censure

naive.meaning: marked by or showing unaffected simplicity
naive.breif: No one likes being called naive, since it means you lack sophistication or street smarts.

adjective: marked by or showing unaffected simplicity and lack of guile or worldly experience
lacking information or instruction
inexperienced
not initiated; deficient in relevant experience
of or created by one without formal training; simple or naive in style

example: a teenager's naive ignorance of life
he took part in the experiment as a naive subject

impassive.meaning: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
impassive.breif: Someone who doesn't seem to react — who is always "taking a pass" in the conversation of life can be described as impassive.

adjective: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited
deliberately impassive in manner

erratic.breif: The adjective erratic describes things that are unpredictable, unusual, and that deviate from the norm. An erratic quarterback might completely confuse his receivers waiting for a pass.

adjective: liable to sudden unpredictable change
likely to perform unpredictably
having no fixed course

example: erratic winds are the bane of a sailor

veracity.breif: Veracity sounds like some kind of disease you don't want to catch, but in fact, it means truthfulness. If you question the veracity of a statement or story, you wonder whether it is truthful or accurate.

noun: unwillingness to tell lies

verbose.meaning: using or containing too many words
verbose.breif: If you're verbose, you use far more words than you need to. A verbose book report goes on and on and is packed with long, complicated words that aren't at all necessary.

adjective: using or containing too many words

solicitous.breif: When you hear the word solicitous, think of your mom — attentive, caring, and concerned. It's nice when your waiter gives you good service, but if he or she is solicitous, the hovering might annoy you.

adjective: full of anxiety and concern
showing hovering attentiveness

abscond.meaning: run away, often taking something or somebody along
abscond.breif: Abscond is to escape, often taking something along. As a kid, you may have absconded from your lemonade stand — with the coffee can of cash in hand, and your bewildered sister still filling cups for your customers.

verb: run away; usually includes taking something or somebody along

example: the accountant absconded with the cash from the safe

lethargic.breif: When you feel lethargic, you're sluggish or lacking energy. Being sleepy or hungry can make anyone lethargic.

adjective: deficient in alertness or activity

example: bullfrogs became lethargic with the first cold nights

disseminate.breif: Disseminate means to spread information, knowledge, opinions widely. Semin- derives from the Latin word for seed; the idea with disseminate is that information travels like seeds sown by a farmer.

latent.meaning: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized
latent.breif: Latent is an adjective that you use to describe something that is capable of becoming active or at hand, though it is not currently so.

adjective: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized
(pathology) not presently active

aberrant.meaning: markedly different from an accepted norm
aberrant.breif: Use the adjective aberrant to describe unusual conduct. Sitting in a bathtub and singing show tunes all day long might be considered aberrant behavior.

adjective: markedly different from an accepted norm
noun: one whose behavior departs substantially from the norm of a group

ambivalent.meaning: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow
ambivalent.breif: If you can't decide how you feel about something, declare yourself ambivalent about it.

adjective: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow

rancid.meaning: having an offensive smell or taste
rancid.breif: Rancid means sour, rotten, and nasty and refers most specifically to the sharp bad smell of decomposing oils or fats. "Rancid" is a great name for a post-punk band, but a lousy way to describe the sauce on your eggs Benedict.

adjective: (used of decomposing oils or fats) having a rank smell or taste usually due to a chemical change or decomposition
smelling of fermentation or staleness

rancorous.breif: The adjective rancorous comes in handy when you're describing someone's bitter grudge, like the attitude of your cousin who still won't speak to you after the April Fool's Day prank you played four years ago.

adjective: showing deep-seated resentment

cavalier.meaning: showing a lack of concern or seriousness
cavalier.breif: Someone who is cavalier has a dismissive attitude and regards other people as inferior. If you think you know more than your teacher and never bother doing homework, your parents might complain that you are cavalier about your studies.

adjective: given to haughty disregard of others
noun: a gallant or courtly gentleman

altruistic.meaning: showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others
altruistic.breif: Someone who is altruistic always puts others first. An altruistic firefighter risks his life to save another's life, while an altruistic mom gives up the last bite of pie so her kid will be happy.

adjective: showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others

pragmatic.breif: To describe a person or a solution that takes a realistic approach, consider the adjective pragmatic. The four-year-old who wants a unicorn for her birthday isn't being very pragmatic.

adjective: concerned with practical matters
of or concerning the theory of pragmatism
guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
noun: an imperial decree that becomes part of the fundamental law of the land

fanatical.meaning: marked by excessive enthusiasm for a cause or idea
fanatical.breif: If you are excessively enthusiastic about something — a sports team, an actor, your religion, saving the whales, a certain brand of chocolate — then you are fanatical about it.

adjective: marked by excessive enthusiasm for and intense devotion to a cause or idea

monotone.breif: Monotone is a droning, unchanging tone. Nothing can put you to sleep quite as effectively as a teacher talking in a monotone.

noun: an unchanging intonation
a single tone repeated with different words or different rhythms (especially in rendering liturgical texts)
adjective: sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch
of a sequence or function; consistently increasing and never decreasing or consistently decreasing and never increasing in value

adamant.meaning: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
adamant.breif: If you stubbornly refuse to change your mind about something, you are adamant about it.

noun: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
adjective: impervious to pleas, persuasion, requests, or reason

example: he is adamant in his refusal to change his mind

acumen.breif: If you have acumen, you are very sharp at what you do. You hope your accountant and your surgeon are both known for their acumen.

noun: shrewdness shown by keen insight
a tapering point

ephemeral.meaning: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day
ephemeral.breif: Something that is fleeting or short-lived is ephemeral, like a fly that lives for one day or text messages flitting from cellphone to cellphone.

noun: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day in its winged form
adjective: lasting a very short time

aggrandize.meaning: embellish; increase the scope, power, or importance of
aggrandize.breif: If you are a window washer, but you refer to yourself as a "vista enhancement specialist," then you are aggrandizing your job title — that is, making it sound greater than it is.

banal.meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
banal.breif: If something is boring and unoriginal, it's banal. Banal things are dull as dishwater.

adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

meticulous.meaning: marked by precise accordance with details
meticulous.breif: Someone who is meticulous pays extreme attention to detail. If that person is, say, your surgeon or your accountant, you'll definitely want them to be meticulous!

adjective: marked by precise accordance with details
marked by extreme care in treatment of details

eccentric.meaning: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual
eccentric.breif: You're most likely to encounter the adjective eccentric in a description of an unusual or quirky person — like a scatterbrained aunt who leaves her life savings to her cat.

adjective: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual
not having a common center; not concentric
noun: a person with an unusual or odd personality
a person of a specified kind (usually with many eccentricities)

harried.meaning: troubled persistently, especially with petty annoyances
harried.breif: Someone who is harried is feeling the stress of being rushed, overworked, or harassed. A harried parent might be exhausted but still have to make 3 dozen cupcakes for school and help with a science project.

adjective: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances

analogous.meaning: similar or equivalent in some respects
analogous.breif: Use the adjective analogous to describe something that is similar to something else and can be compared to another.

adjective: similar or equivalent in some respects though otherwise dissimilar
corresponding in function but not in evolutionary origin

example: brains and computers are often considered analogous
the wings of a bee and those of a hummingbird are analogous

hackneyed.meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
hackneyed.breif: Hackneyed is a word for language that doesn't pack a punch since it's overused and trite. "Roses are red, violets are..." — enough already?! That's hackneyed stuff.

adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

disparate.meaning: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
disparate.breif: The trunk of some people's cars may contain items as disparate as old clothes, rotting food, and possibly a missing relative. Disparate things are very different from each other.

adjective: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
including markedly dissimilar elements

example: such disparate attractions as grand opera and game fishing
a disparate aggregate of creeds and songs and prayers

sublime.meaning: of high moral or intellectual value
sublime.breif: In common use, sublime is an adjective meaning "awe-inspiringly grand, excellent, or impressive," like the best chocolate fudge sundae you've ever had.

adjective: of high moral or intellectual value; elevated in nature or style
worthy of adoration or reverence
inspiring awe
lifted up or set high
verb: change or cause to change directly from a solid into a vapor without first melting
vaporize and then condense right back again

example: the sublime beauty of the night
"their hearts were jocund and sublime"- Milton

enigmatic.breif: Something that's enigmatic is tough to figure out. It's puzzling and even mysterious, like those weird secret college societies, Mona Lisa's smile, or the New York Times crossword.

adjective: not clear to the understanding
resembling an oracle in obscurity of thought

example: I didn't grasp the meaning of that enigmatic comment until much later
so enigmatic that priests might have to clarify it

insipid.meaning: lacking interest or significance or impact
insipid.breif: Something insipid is lacking in flavor or interest. You'll probably find the generic poems inside of greeting cards insipid.

adjective: lacking interest or significance or impact
lacking taste or flavor or tang

conjecture.meaning: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
conjecture.breif: Can you guess what conjecture means? It's a word to use when you are not sure of something and have to "guess or surmise."

verb: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
noun: reasoning that involves the formation of conclusions from incomplete evidence
a hypothesis that has been formed by speculating or conjecturing (usually with little hard evidence)
a message expressing an opinion based on incomplete evidence

example: he dismissed it as mere conjecture

laconic.breif: Laconic is an adjective that describes a style of speaking or writing that uses only a few words, often to express complex thoughts and ideas.  A more laconic way to write that last sentence might be this: laconic means brief.

adjective: brief and to the point; effectively cut short

exigent.breif: When you describe something as exigent, you are saying it requires attention: it can't be ignored.

adjective: demanding attention
requiring precise accuracy

example: "regarded literary questions as exigent and momentous"- H.L.Mencken
became more exigent over his pronunciation

disparage.breif: If you haven't got anything nice to say, then it's time to disparage someone. It means to belittle or degrade a person or idea.

polemical.meaning: of or involving dispute or controversy
polemical.breif: The adjective polemical describes something related to an argument or controversy. To keep the peace, avoid discussing politics at Thanksgiving, which usually deteriorates into a polemical argument with Uncle Bob. Better stick to football or apple versus pumpkin pie.

adjective: of or involving dispute or controversy

asperity.breif: Asperity is the harsh tone or behavior people exhibit when they’re angry, impatient, or just miserable. Did your supervisor snap “Late again!” when you showed up 20 minutes after your shift was supposed to start? She's speaking with asperity.

noun: harshness of manner
something hard to endure

dearth.breif: If there is a dearth of something, there is not enough of it. A dearth of cupcakes is unfortunate, but a dearth of nutritious food is a serious problem.

noun: an insufficient quantity or number
an acute insufficiency

oblivion.meaning: the state of being disregarded or forgotten
oblivion.breif: Oblivion is the state of being forgotten. Your uncle dreamed of being a rock star, but after recording one hit song, he faded into oblivion.

noun: the state of being disregarded or forgotten
total forgetfulness

example: he sought the great oblivion of sleep

adolescent.meaning: a person who is older than 12 but younger than 20
adolescent.breif: Adolescent is just a fancy word for teenager — someone who is no longer a child but is not yet an adult. The word can also be used as an adjective. For example, a particular clothing line might be geared toward adolescent girls.

noun: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity
adjective: in the state of development between puberty and maturity
being of the age 13 through 19
displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
relating to or peculiar to or suggestive of an adolescent

atrocity.breif: Atrocities, acts of outrageous cruelty, are often committed during wars and armed conflicts.

noun: an act of atrocious cruelty
the quality of being shockingly cruel and inhumane

disdain.meaning: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
disdain.breif: If you feel that something isn't worthy of your consideration, you may disdain it (or treat it with disdain).

noun: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
a communication that indicates lack of respect by patronizing the recipient

disingenuous.breif: Use the adjective disingenuous to describe behavior that's not totally honest or sincere. It's disingenuous when people pretend to know less about something than they really do.

adjective: not straightforward or candid; giving a false appearance of frankness

example: "an ambitious, disingenuous, philistine, and hypocritical operator, who...exemplified...the most disagreeable traits of his time"- David Cannadine

truculent.breif: If you are quick to argue, always looking for a fight, and hard to please, you are truculent. You can also write a truculent essay, and fans upset by a loss can become truculent.

adjective: defiantly aggressive

example: a truculent speech against the new government

ubiquitous.breif: It's everywhere! It's everywhere! When something seems like it's present in all places at the same time, reach for the adjective ubiquitous.

adjective: being present everywhere at once

superfluous.meaning: more than is needed, desired, or required
superfluous.breif: When something is so unnecessary that it could easily be done away with, like a fifth wheel on a car or a fifth person on a double date, call it superfluous.

adjective: more than is needed, desired, or required
serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being

corroborate.breif: To corroborate is to back someone else’s story. If you swear to your teacher that you didn't throw the spitball, and your friends corroborate your story by promising that you were concentrating on math homework, she might actually believe you.

verb: support with evidence or authority or make more certain or confirm
establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts

mundane.meaning: found in the ordinary course of events
mundane.breif: An ordinary, unexciting thing can be called mundane: "Superman hid his heroic feats by posing as his mundane alter ego, Clark Kent."

adjective: found in the ordinary course of events
concerned with the world or worldly matters
belonging to this earth or world; not ideal or heavenly

example: yet a mundane wonder of unimagined kind

accord.breif: An accord is an agreement between groups or even nations, like a formal peace accord that prevents war or the accord between you and your sister specifying who gets to use the car on which days.

noun: concurrence of opinion
sympathetic compatibility
harmony of people's opinions or actions or characters
a written agreement between two states or sovereigns

example: we are in accord with your proposal

exasperation.breif: If you've ever become so frustrated with someone or something that you feel like you're at the end of your rope, you have experienced exasperation. You are fed up!

noun: actions that cause great irritation (or even anger)
an exasperated feeling of annoyance

eminent.meaning: standing above others in quality or position
eminent.breif: Anyone highly regarded or prominent is eminent. Eminent people are very successful at their jobs. If you’ve heard of Neil deGrasse Tyson, it’s probably because he’s an eminent astrophysicist.

adjective: standing above others in quality or position
(used of persons) standing above others in character or attainment or reputation
having an illustrious reputation; respected
of imposing height; especially standing out above others

ambiguity.meaning: unclearness by virtue of having more than one meaning
ambiguity.breif: Something with ambiguity is unclear. Think about the sentence, "Jill saw the man with binoculars." If you are wondering whether Jill or the man had the binoculars, you are noticing the ambiguity, or the double meaning, of this sentence.

noun: unclearness by virtue of having more than one meaning
an expression whose meaning cannot be determined from its context

aberration.meaning: a state or condition markedly different from the norm
aberration.breif: An aberration is something strange that rarely occurs. An example of an aberration is when the temperature in Minnesota hits 90 degrees in January — it's nice and warm, but it's really strange.

noun: a state or condition markedly different from the norm
a disorder in one's mental state
an optical phenomenon resulting from the failure of a lens or mirror to produce a good image

complaisance.meaning: a tendency to try to please or yield to the will of others
complaisance.breif: Complaisance is a quality of being eager to please or happy to follow instructions. Your new puppy's complaisance is going to make her easy to train.

noun: a disposition or tendency to yield to the will of others

obstinate.meaning: marked by tenacious unwillingness to yield
obstinate.breif: When someone is beyond stubborn, use the word obstinate instead: "You obstinate old mule! Get out of my way!"

adjective: tenaciously unwilling or marked by tenacious unwillingness to yield
stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
resistant to guidance or discipline

example: an obstinate child with a violent temper
he obstinates himself against all rational arguments

noun: intelligence manifested by being astute (as in business dealings)

erudite.breif: If you call someone erudite, that means they show great learning. After you've earned your second Ph.D., you will be truly erudite.

adjective: having or showing profound knowledge

culminate.meaning: end, especially to reach a final or climactic stage
culminate.breif: The verb culminate is used to describe a high point or a climactic stage in a process. For example, the goal of a Major League baseball team is to have their season culminate in a World Series victory.

verb: end, especially to reach a final or climactic stage
bring to a head or to the highest point
reach the highest or most decisive point
reach the highest altitude or the meridian, of a celestial body
rise to, or form, a summit

example: The meeting culminated in a tearful embrace
The helmet culminated in a crest

acquiesce.breif: To acquiesce is to agree to something or to give in. If your kid sister is refusing to hand over the television remote, you hope she acquiesces before your favorite show comes on.

diffidence.breif: The noun diffidence refers to a lack of self-confidence. Your diffidence might be the reason why you never say "hi" to the cute guy or gal in the elevator or why you never ask for a raise.

noun: lack of self-confidence

disabuse.meaning: free somebody from an erroneous belief
disabuse.breif: Disabuse means to free someone of a belief that is not true. Many teachers of health find that when they teach, they spend as much energy disabusing kids of false beliefs as they do giving them the facts.

frivolous.meaning: not serious in content, attitude, or behavior
frivolous.breif: Frivolous things are silly or unnecessary. If something is frivolous, then you don't need it.

adjective: not serious in content or attitude or behavior

vacillate.breif: Vacillate means to waver back and forth, unable to decide. You might vacillate between ordering waffles and pancakes at your favorite diner — it’s hard to pick just one when both are so tasty!

verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
move or sway in a rising and falling or wavelike pattern

example: the line on the monitor vacillated

propriety.breif: Propriety is following what is socially acceptable in speech and behavior. Your little brother might offend your sense of propriety by burping loudly at the dinner table.

noun: correct or appropriate behavior

lugubrious.breif: Funerals are lugubrious. So are rainy days and Mondays. Anything that makes you sad, gloomy, or mournful can be called lugubrious.

adjective: excessively mournful

persistent.breif: If something is persistent, it just won't stop. If you're persistent in your suggestions for a trip to Mexico, maybe your parents will eventually give in and take you there.

adjective: stubbornly unyielding
never-ceasing
continually recurring to the mind
retained; not shed

example: persistent leaves remain attached past maturity

implacable.meaning: incapable of being appeased or pacified
implacable.breif: An implacable person just can’t be appeased. If you really offended your best friend and tried every kind of apology but she refused to speak to you again, you could describe her as implacable.

adjective: incapable of being placated

obdurate.breif: Obdurate is a formal word meaning stubborn. If you want to major in English, but your parents are obdurate that you should go premed, they might go so far as to threaten not to pay your tuition.

adjective: stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
showing unfeeling resistance to tender feelings

example: the child's misery would move even the most obdurate heart

abstain.meaning: refrain from doing, consuming, or partaking in something
abstain.breif: If you abstain from something, you restrain yourself from consuming it. People usually abstain from things that are considered vices — like eating French fries every day for lunch.

verb: choose not to partake in or consume

impetuous.meaning: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought
impetuous.breif: Someone impetuous acts too hastily or carelessly. Hotheaded, impulsive folks are impetuous.

adjective: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
marked by violent force

example: an impetuous display of spending and gambling

decorum.breif: Decorum is proper and polite behavior. If you let out a big belch at a fancy dinner party, you're not showing much decorum.

noun: propriety in manners and conduct
the fitness of a composition’s style to its subject

eloquent.breif: When you're eloquent, you have a way with words. An eloquent speaker expresses herself clearly and powerfully. Even though eloquent usually describes oral speech, it can also be used to describe powerful writing.

adjective: expressing yourself readily, clearly, effectively

providential.breif: If your best friend pulls up beside you in her convertible just as your bike gets a flat tire, you could call it providential, or magically lucky.

adjective: peculiarly fortunate or appropriate; as if by divine intervention
relating to or characteristic of providence
resulting from divine providence

example: "assumption that nature operates only according to a providential plan"- M.R.Cohen

prodigious.meaning: great in size, force, extent, or degree
prodigious.breif: Something exceptional, substantial, or great is prodigious. A blizzard includes prodigious wind and snow. A prodigious writer is one who can write a lot and do it well.

adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
far beyond what is usual in magnitude or degree
of momentous or ominous significance

zeal.breif: Zeal is dedication or enthusiasm for something. If you have zeal, you're willing, energized, and motivated.

noun: a feeling of strong eagerness (usually in favor of a person or cause)
prompt willingness
excessive fervor to do something or accomplish some end

example: he felt a kind of religious zeal
they disliked his zeal in demonstrating his superiority
he had an absolute zeal for litigation

puerile.meaning: displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
puerile.breif: Some people like their movies to have sophisticated humor and others prefer the more puerile humor of pratfalls or jokes about smelly underwear, inappropriate belching, and passing gas.

adjective: displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
of or characteristic of a child

obfuscate.breif: Some people are experts at obfuscating the truth by being evasive, unclear, or obscure in the telling of the facts. The people who are good at obfuscating would include defense lawyers and teenagers asked about their plans for Saturday night.

apathy.meaning: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
apathy.breif: Use the noun apathy when someone isn't interested in the important things that are happening. You might feel apathy for the political process after watching candidates bicker tediously with one another.

noun: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
the trait of lacking enthusiasm for or interest in things generally

benevolent.meaning: showing or motivated by sympathy and understanding
benevolent.breif: Choose the adjective benevolent for someone who does good deeds or shows goodwill. If your teacher collects homework with a benevolent smile, she's hoping that you've done a good job.

adjective: showing or motivated by sympathy and understanding and generosity
intending or showing kindness
generous in providing aid to others
generous in assistance to the poor

predicament.breif: If you're engaged to get married but suddenly fall in love with someone else, you have gotten yourself into quite a predicament. A predicament is a difficult, confusing, and unpleasant situation.

noun: a situation from which extrication is difficult especially an unpleasant or trying one

example: finds himself in a most awkward predicament

confine.breif: Confine is all about setting limits. If you are confined to the house, it means you can't leave it. If you're really sick, you might be confined to your bed.

verb: restrict or confine, "I limit you to two visits to the pub a day"
deprive of freedom; take into confinement
to close within bounds, limit or hold back from movement
prevent from leaving or from being removed

progeny.meaning: the immediate descendants of a person
progeny.breif: Progeny means "offspring" or "children." You and your brothers are the progeny of your parents, and your cat's new litter of kittens is her progeny.

noun: the immediate descendants of a person

repertoire.meaning: the range of skills in a particular field or occupation
repertoire.breif: Repertoire refers to the full supply of what you can do. A singer's repertoire is all the songs he can sing. A chef's repertoire is what she knows how to cook.

noun: the entire range of skills or aptitudes or devices used in a particular field or occupation
a collection of works (plays, songs, operas, ballets) that an artist or company can perform and do perform for short intervals on a regular schedule

impelled.meaning: urged or forced to action through moral pressure

adjective: urged or forced to action through moral pressure

example: felt impelled to take a stand against the issue

etched.meaning: cut or impressed into a surface

adjective: cut or impressed into a surface

prowl.meaning: move about in or as if in a predatory manner
prowl.breif: If you move stealthily — like you're looking for something to prey on — then you prowl. Your cat might prowl around the room and pounce on your feet, which is cute if you're awake, but annoying when you're asleep.

verb: move about in or as if in a predatory manner
loiter about, with no apparent aim
noun: the act of prowling (walking about in a stealthy manner)

example: The suspicious stranger prowls the streets of the town

propensity.breif: A propensity is a natural tendency to behave in a certain way. We all have propensities — things we tend to do. Dogs have a propensity to bark, and many people have a propensity for getting annoyed by it.

noun: a natural inclination
an inclination to do something
a disposition to behave in a certain way

example: the propensity of disease to spread

comprehend.breif: To comprehend something is to understand it, like when you have to read a difficult passage more than once in order to comprehend it.

verb: become aware of through the senses
include in scope; include as part of something broader; have as one's sphere or territory

example: Do you comprehend the meaning of this letter?

thoroughly.breif: Thoroughly means exhaustively and completely. No matter how thoroughly you clean every carpet, shelf, and windowpane in a house, there is always more dust to be found.

adverb: completely and absolutely (`good' is sometimes used informally for `thoroughly')

erroneous.breif: The adjective erroneous describes something or someone as mistaken and incorrect. Early explorers had the erroneous notion that the oceans were full of dragons.

adjective: containing or characterized by error

espouse.meaning: choose and follow a theory, idea, policy, etc.
espouse.breif: Use the verb espouse to describe the actions of someone who lives according to specific beliefs, such as your friends who espouse environmentalism and as a result walk whenever possible instead of taking the car.

verb: choose and follow; as of theories, ideas, policies, strategies or plans
take up the cause, ideology, practice, method, of someone and use it as one's own

fallacious.meaning: containing or based on incorrect reasoning
fallacious.breif: Something fallacious is a mistake that comes from too little information or unsound sources. Predictions that the whole state of California will snap off from the rest of North America and float away have proven to be fallacious — for now, anyway.

adjective: containing or based on a fallacy
based on an incorrect or misleading notion or information
intended to deceive

decisive.breif: If you make decisions quickly, you are someone who is decisive. A decisive event can settle something, like a war.

adjective: characterized by decision and firmness
determining or having the power to determine an outcome
forming or having the nature of a turning point or crisis
unmistakable

example: an able and decisive young woman
had a decisive lead in the polls

penning.meaning: the act of creating written works

noun: the act of creating written works

automation.meaning: the act of implementing the control of equipment
automation.breif: Automation means making something automatic, or mechanized. If there's smoke in your house and your smoke detector is set up to "call" the fire department, that's an example of automation.

noun: the act of implementing the control of equipment with advanced technology; usually involving electronic hardware
equipment used to achieve automatic control or operation
the condition of being automatically operated or controlled

example: automation replaces human workers by machines
this factory floor is a showcase for automation and robotic equipment

adjective: fully understood or grasped

noun: a military training exercise
a plan for attaining a particular goal
a deliberate coordinated movement requiring dexterity and skill
a move made to gain a tactical end
an action aimed at evading an opponent
verb: act in order to achieve a certain goal
perform a movement in military or naval tactics in order to secure an advantage in attack or defense
direct the course; determine the direction of travelling

worthwhile.meaning: sufficiently valuable to justify the investment of time
worthwhile.breif: Things that are worthwhile are good — they're worth the time or money you spend on them.

adjective: sufficiently valuable to justify the investment of time or interest

prominent.breif: If you're looking for an adjective that means "sticking out above the rest; famous," consider prominent. A prominent person might be the big star, the head honcho, the top dog — not just any ordinary person.

adjective: conspicuous in position or importance
having a quality that thrusts itself into attention

example: a new theory is the most prominent feature of the book

catapult.meaning: an engine providing medieval artillery used during sieges
catapult.breif: A catapult is something that hurls things through the air, like a catapult that sends pumpkins flying in an annual Halloween competition.

noun: an engine that provided medieval artillery used during sieges; a heavy war engine for hurling large stones and other missiles
a device that launches aircraft from a warship
a plaything consisting of a Y-shaped stick with elastic between the arms; used to propel small stones
verb: shoot forth or launch, as if from a catapult
hurl as if with a sling

example: the enemy catapulted rocks towards the fort

adjective: surrounded by hostile forces

conviction.meaning: an unshakable belief in something without need for proof
conviction.breif: A conviction is something certain: a judgment of guilty in court and a strong belief are both convictions.

noun: an unshakable belief in something without need for proof or evidence
(criminal law) a final judgment of guilty in a criminal case and the punishment that is imposed

example: the conviction came as no surprise

compelling.meaning: capable of arousing and holding the attention
compelling.breif: Compelling means attractive, or irresistible, or really, really convincing. You know your argument for backpacking across Europe is compelling when your parents not only let you go but also pay for all your expenses.

adjective: capable of arousing and holding the attention
tending to persuade by forcefulness of argument
driving or forcing

elucidate.breif: If you elucidate something, you explain it very clearly. If you don't understand fractions, a visit to the pie shop may elucidate the subject for you.

verb: make free from confusion or ambiguity; make clear

rein.meaning: one of a pair of long straps used to control a horse
rein.breif: Rein is both a noun and a verb for guiding and restraining. You can use the long strap, or rein, on a horse to control its speed and direction, and you can rein in your own tongue by closing your mouth.

noun: one of a pair of long straps (usually connected to the bit or the headpiece) used to control a horse
any means of control
verb: control and direct with or as if by reins
stop or check by or as if by a pull at the reins
stop or slow up one's horse or oneself by or as if by pulling the reins

example: he took up the reins of government
He reined in his horses in front of the post office
They reined in in front of the post office

incessant.meaning: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing
incessant.breif: Something incessant continues without interruption. When you're on a cross-country flight, it's tough to tolerate the incessant crying of a baby.

adjective: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing

example: night and day we live with the incessant noise of the city

falter.meaning: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way
falter.breif: Falter means to hesitate, stumble, or waver, and everything from faith to voices can do it. So if you want to keep your bride or groom happy, it's best not to falter when it's your turn to say "I do."

verb: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way
noun: the act of pausing uncertainly

example: The speaker faltered when he saw his opponent enter the room

etch.meaning: carve or cut a design or letters into
etch.breif: If you etch something you are cutting into it. You can etch "I ♥ U" into a tree trunk with a pocket knife or etch your initials in your desk with a key (if the teacher's not looking).

verb: carve or cut a design or letters into
carve or cut into a block used for printing or print from such a block
selectively dissolve the surface of (a semiconductor or printed circuit) with a solvent, laser, or stream of electrons
cause to stand out or be clearly defined or visible

example: He etched her image into the surface

immemorial.breif: Anything immemorial is very, very old. You're most likely to hear this word in the phrase "time immemorial," a common way to say "so long ago that no one remembers it."

adjective: long past; beyond the limits of memory or tradition or recorded history

delve.meaning: turn up, loosen, or remove earth
delve.breif: The verb delve means to dig into, loosen, or investigate. She delved into her family's history and discovered an inventor, a checkers champion, and a circus equestrian in her ancestry.

verb: turn up, loosen, or remove earth
search for something in a receptacle or container
consider in detail and subject to an analysis in order to discover essential features or meaning

bode.breif: The verb bode suggests forecasting. Something bodes well when the clues or signs imply a favorable outcome. But if something bodes ill, you’d better watch out!

repose.breif: Repose is a formal or literary term used to mean the act of resting, or the state of being at rest. Repose is also a state of mind: freedom from worry.

noun: freedom from activity (work or strain or responsibility)
the absence of mental stress or anxiety
a disposition free from stress or emotion
verb: lean in a comfortable resting position
put or confide something in a person or thing

example: took his repose by the swimming pool
He was reposing on the couch
These philosophers reposed the law in the people
The nation reposed its confidence in the King

unscrupulous.breif: Use the adjective unscrupulous to describe someone who behaves in a dishonest or unethical way.

adjective: without scruples or principles

example: unscrupulous politicos who would be happy to sell...their country in order to gain power

juncture.meaning: the shape or manner in which things come together
juncture.breif: A juncture is a crucial point in time when a decision must be made. At this juncture, a president might say, the government must decide whether to go ahead with war or to try to solve things diplomatically.

noun: the shape or manner in which things come together and a connection is made
an event that occurs at a critical time
a crisis situation or point in time when a critical decision must be made

example: at such junctures he always had an impulse to leave
at that juncture he had no idea what to do

fathom.meaning: a linear unit of measurement for water depth
fathom.breif: To fathom something is to understand it thoroughly. It's usually used in the negative, as in "I can't fathom why he doesn't want to go along with us."

noun: a linear unit of measurement (equal to 6 feet) for water depth
(mining) a unit of volume (equal to 6 cubic feet) used in measuring bodies of ore
verb: measure the depth of (a body of water) with a sounding line

diligent.meaning: quietly and steadily persevering in detail or exactness
diligent.breif: Someone who is diligent works hard and carefully. If you want to write the epic history of your family, you'll have to be very diligent in tracking down and interviewing all of your relatives.

adjective: quietly and steadily persevering especially in detail or exactness
characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks

example: a diligent detective investigates all clues

ignominious.meaning: deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.breif: Losing a football game stinks, but losing a game where, at the end, you are lying face down in a puddle of mud and the fans are burning effigies of you in the streets? That is an ignominious defeat.

adjective: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame

galore.breif: At a party with more cupcakes than anyone could imagine, you’ll hear guests say, “There are cupcakes galore!”  Galore means there’s so much that it’s unbelievable.

adjective: existing in abundance
in great numbers

imbibe.breif: Imbibe is a fancy word for "drink."  If you need to imbibe ten cups of coffee just to get out of the house, you might have a caffeine problem.

verb: take (gas, light or heat) into a solution
receive into the mind and retain

succinctly.meaning: with concise and precise brevity; to the point
succinctly.breif: To say something succinctly is to say it briefly, fitting your points into one concise statement. It's a talent rarely enjoyed and much appreciated.  You succinctly stated your case and sat down to great applause, not to mention great relief.

adverb: with concise and precise brevity; to the point

example: Please state your case as succinctly as possible

tandem.meaning: an arrangement of objects or persons one behind another
tandem.breif: Tandem describes an arrangement where people or animals are in formation, one behind the other. Couples attached at the hip sometimes like to ride tandem bicycles, which allow two people to pedal the same bike. How cute.

noun: an arrangement of two or more objects or persons one behind another
a bicycle with two sets of pedals and two seats

example: ride tandem on a bicycle built for two

unbridled.breif: Unbridled means unrestrained. When you find out that you just won the lottery, feel free to jump up and down with unbridled joy. Go ahead, most people would probably let loose in the same way.

adjective: not restrained or controlled

maudlin.breif: You can use maudlin to describe something that brings tears to your eyes, or makes you feel very emotional. Tearjerkers like "Forrest Gump" and "Titanic" can be described as maudlin.

adjective: effusively or insincerely emotional

wheedle.meaning: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering
wheedle.breif: To wheedle is to sweet talk, or flatter someone in the hopes of getting something in return. You might try to wheedle a meter maid into not giving you a parking ticket. Good luck with that.

verb: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

amelioration.meaning: the act of relieving ills and changing for the better
amelioration.breif: Amelioration is a process that makes something better. A philanthropist might devote her life to the amelioration of poverty and hunger.

noun: the act of relieving ills and changing for the better

brood.meaning: hang over, as of something threatening, dark, or menacing
brood.breif: A brood is a group of young born at the same time — like a brood of chicks — but your parents might use the word for you and your siblings: "We're taking the whole brood to the movies tonight."

verb: hang over, as of something threatening, dark, or menacing
think moodily or anxiously about something
be in a huff; be silent or sullen
be in a huff and display one's displeasure
noun: the young of an animal cared for at one time

example: The terrible vision brooded over her all day long

whimsy.meaning: an odd or fanciful or capricious idea
