whimsy.breif: Whimsy is what a person who's a dreamer and out of step with the real world might have lots of. People who are full of whimsy are odd, but often fanciful and lovely, like Harry Potter's friend Luna Lovegood.

noun: an odd or fanciful or capricious idea
the trait of acting unpredictably and more from whim or caprice than from reason or judgment

example: he had a whimsy about flying to the moon

chatoyant.meaning: varying in color when seen in different lights or from different angles

adjective: varying in color when seen in different lights or from different angles

conflate.breif: Conflate is a more formal way to say "mix together," and it's typically used for texts or ideas. You probably wouldn't say you conflated the ingredients for a cake, but if you blended two different stories together to make a new one, conflate would work.

example: This harks back to a previous remark of his

besiege.meaning: surround so as to force to give up
besiege.breif: To besiege means to attack with an army, or to pester with many requests. When all your teachers ask you to hand in assignments on the same day, you can end up feeling besieged.

verb: surround so as to force to give up
harass, as with questions or requests
cause to feel distressed or worried

example: The press photographers besieged the movie star
She was besieged by so many problems that she got discouraged

apprehend.breif: To apprehend is to capture or arrest, as when the police try to apprehend criminals and bring them to justice. You also apprehend a concept when you understand it, grasping or capturing its meaning.

verb: understand or perceive the meaning of something

imperative.breif: When something absolutely has to be done and cannot be put off, use the adjective imperative.

adjective: requiring attention or action
relating to verbs in the imperative mood
noun: some duty that is essential and urgent
a mood that expresses an intention to influence the listener's behavior

example: as nuclear weapons proliferate, preventing war becomes imperative

compel.breif: Compel means to force or drive someone to do something. Even if you don't like toast, when you visit the toast-eating natives of Shrintakook Island, you'll be compelled to eat it, or they will not trust you.
example: We compel all students to fill out this form

fortify.breif: If you add nutrients to something you fortify it. Food scientists have found ways to fortify cereal, but in addition to vitamins C and D, they usually add a lot of sugar.

verb: enclose by or as if by a fortification
prepare oneself for a military confrontation

entail.breif: To entail is to involve. A job at a movie theater might entail sweeping popcorn off the floor, probably because watching a movie entails eating popcorn in the dark. It’s a small price to pay!

verb: impose, involve, or imply as a necessary accompaniment or result
limit the inheritance of property to a specific class of heirs
noun: land received by fee tail
the act of entailing property; the creation of a fee tail from a fee simple

prudent.breif: Describe an action as prudent if it is the wise thing to do under the existing circumstances. If you're getting in trouble, it is probably prudent to keep your mouth closed and just listen.

adjective: careful and sensible; marked by sound judgment

pertain.breif: To pertain is to be relevant or somehow associated with something.  If you're a lawyer, you try to find evidence that will pertain to the case and eliminate anything that is not connected.

verb: be a part or attribute of

example: My remark pertained to your earlier comments

fraught.breif: Fraught means filled with something — often something bad. Your Thanksgiving was fraught with awkward moments when your family saw your blue hair, and it only got worse when you told them you'd quit law school to join the circus.

adjective: filled with or attended with
marked by distress

bestow.breif: When you present an honor or a gift to someone, you bestow it, which is the same as giving it, but often classier and more respectful.

emphatic.breif: Emphatic means forceful and clear. Nicole's mother was emphatic when she told her not to come home late again.

adjective: spoken with emphasis
sudden and strong
forceful and definite in expression or action

example: the document contained a particularly emphatic guarantee of religious liberty

preach.breif: To preach is to deliver a sermon or an otherwise powerful message. You may go to church to hear the minister preach, and you may preach tolerance to your friends.

verb: speak, plead, or argue in favor of

example: The minister is not preaching this Sunday

endeavor.breif: When you endeavor to do something, you try hard to make it happen. A determined student might endeavor to get straight As on her report card.

noun: earnest and conscientious activity intended to do or accomplish something
a purposeful or industrious undertaking (especially one that requires effort or boldness)

example: we endeavor to make our customers happy
wished him luck in his endeavor

precedent.meaning: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences
precedent.breif: A precedent is something that sets a standard for future events. It's hard to say what the legal community would do without the word precedent, since so many legal judgments and decisions are based on what came before.

noun: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time
(civil law) a previous legal decision that is used to inform subsequent decisions
a system of jurisprudence based on judicial precedents rather than statutory laws
a subject mentioned earlier (preceding in time)
adjective: preceding in time, order, or significance

gratify.breif:
To gratify is to satisfy. Bringing home an A in math would gratify your math tutor. 
Gratify can also mean to give in. You probably shouldn't gratify your urge to scream in class.

drudgery.breif: If you’ve ever had to do the laundry, wash the dishes, make the meals, change the bedding, vacuum the house, and clean the bathrooms day after day, you’ve experienced drudgery. Drudgery is hard, mindless, backbreaking work.

noun: hard monotonous routine work

autochthonous.breif: Use the adjective autochthonous to say that something is native to an area. If kane toads originated in your area, then they’re an autochthonous species.

adjective: originating where it is found
of rocks, deposits, etc.; found where they and their constituents were formed

example: autochthonous rocks and people and folktales

satiate.breif: If you just can't get enough popcorn, even the jumbo tub at the movie theater may not be enough to satiate, or satisfy, your desire.

verb: overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself
adjective: supplied (especially fed) to satisfaction

clique.meaning: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose
clique.breif: A clique is an exclusive group of people or friends. Before Rudolph pulled Santa's sled through the fog, the clique of flying reindeer never let him play their reindeer games.

noun: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose

befuddle.breif: To befuddle is to confuse. A sticky exam question can befuddle you, or an awkward question about your whereabouts the night before (how can you remember? You were befuddled, after all.)

verb: be confusing or perplexing to; cause to be unable to think clearly

example: This question befuddled even the teacher

noun: an assistant to a bishop

onslaught.breif: Onslaught is a military term that refers to an attack against an enemy. It's safe to say that no one wants to be caught on the receiving end of an onslaught, because there will be lots of danger, destruction and probably death.

noun: (military) an offensive against an enemy (using weapons)
a sudden and severe onset of trouble
the rapid and continuous delivery of linguistic communication (spoken or written)

treason.meaning: a crime that undermines the offender's government
treason.breif: Hacking your brother’s email account and sharing all his secrets with your mom could be considered an act of personal treason, meaning you have betrayed your brother.

noun: a crime that undermines the offender's government
disloyalty by virtue of subversive behavior
an act of deliberate betrayal

cognition.meaning: the psychological result of perception and reasoning
cognition.breif: Cognition is the act of thinking, perceiving, and understanding. It's cognition that makes it possible for you to learn a foreign language.

noun: the psychological result of perception and learning and reasoning

cordon.meaning: a series of sentinels or posts enclosing some place or thing
cordon.breif: That yellow police tape and group of officers encircling the crime scene? That's a kind of cordon — something set up to guard something.

noun: a series of sentinels or of military posts enclosing or guarding some place or thing
cord or ribbon worn as an insignia of honor or rank
adornment consisting of an ornamental ribbon or cord

procure.breif: In prison movies, there's always a character who is able to procure all sorts of contraband from the inside — magazines, playing cards, special soap. If you procure something, you get it or bring it about by special effort.

verb: arrange for sexual partners for others

obsolete.breif: Use the adjective obsolete for something that is out of date. As the Rolling Stones song "Out of Time" goes, "You're obsolete, my baby, my poor old-fashioned baby."

adjective: no longer in use
